intro: Silene pachyphylla, commonly known as the thick-leaved campion, is a perennial herb native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its thick, fleshy leaves that store water, an adaptation to its harsh, dry environment. The plant produces striking pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are often covered in a dense layer of fine hairs, which help reduce water loss and protect against intense sunlight. Silene pachyphylla is also known for its ability to thrive in poor soil conditions, making it a resilient species in desert ecosystems.
